title: English Grammar Foundations
subject: english-grammar
description: Build confidence with parts of speech, sentence structure, verb tenses, and punctuation through short practice questions.

items.text: Which word is a noun in this sentence? "The cat slept."
items.explain: "Cat" is a noun because it names a person, place, thing, or idea.
wrongExplanations: "The" is an article (determiner), not a noun.
"Slept" is a verb; it shows an action.
There is a noun in the sentence: "cat".

items.text: Choose the verb in the sentence: "Birds fly."
items.explain: "Fly" is the verb because it tells what the subject does.

items.text: Which word is an adjective? "She wore a bright jacket."
items.explain: "Bright" is an adjective because it describes the noun "jacket."

items.text: Which word is an adverb? "He ran quickly."
items.explain: "Quickly" is an adverb because it tells how he ran.
wrongExplanations: "Ran quickly" is a verb phrase; the adverb is "quickly".

items.text: Which sentence is a complete sentence?
items.explain: A complete sentence needs a subject and a verb and expresses a complete thought.
wrongExplanations: This is a fragment; it starts with "Because" and is incomplete.
This is a fragment; it lacks a clear subject.
This is a fragment; it doesn’t express a complete thought.

items.text: Choose the subject in the sentence: "My friends play soccer."
items.explain: "Friends" is the subject because it tells who does the action.
wrongExplanations: "My" describes the subject but isn’t the subject by itself.

items.text: Choose the predicate (what the subject does) in: "The teacher smiled."
items.explain: The predicate includes the verb. Here, the action is "smiled."

items.text: Which sentence is correctly punctuated?
items.explain: "Let's" means "let us" and the comma shows you are speaking to Grandma.
wrongExplanations: Missing comma after "eat"; this changes the meaning.
Missing apostrophe and comma; meaning changes.

items.text: Choose the correct past tense form: "Yesterday, I ___ to the store."
items.explain: "Went" is the simple past tense of "go."
wrongExplanations: "Gone" is a past participle, not simple past here.

items.text: Choose the correct present tense: "She ___ every morning."
items.explain: With "she" (third person singular), we use "runs."

items.text: Choose the correct future tense: "Tomorrow, they ___ the project."
items.explain: Future tense is often formed with "will" + base verb: "will finish."
wrongExplanations: "Finish" is present tense without a future marker.

items.text: Pick the correct form: "They have ___ their homework."
items.explain: "Have" + past participle: "have done."
wrongExplanations: "Did" is simple past, not used with "have" here.
"Doing" is a participle but not the correct form after "have".

items.text: Choose the correctly capitalized sentence.
options: we went to france in july.
We went to france in July.
We went to France in July.
we went to France in july.
items.explain: Capitalize the first word, proper nouns (France), and the month (July).
wrongExplanations: Missing capitalization for the first word, France, and July.
France is a proper noun and should be capitalized.
Missing capitalization for the first word and July.

items.text: Which sentence uses apostrophes correctly?
options: The dog' s bone is missing.
items.explain: "Dog's" shows singular possession: the bone belongs to one dog.
wrongExplanations: "Dogs'" would mean the bone belongs to multiple dogs.
Apostrophe is in the wrong place.

items.text: Choose the sentence that correctly uses quotation marks.
items.explain: In American English, periods usually go inside the quotation marks: "Hello."
wrongExplanations: Missing comma before the quote and capitalization is off for a full sentence quote.
The period should go inside the quotation marks here.

items.text: Choose the correct word: "Their/There/They're going to the park."
items.explain: "They're" is a contraction for "they are": "They are going to the park."

items.text: Choose the correct word: "I would like to ___ a glass of water."
items.explain: "Have" is the correct verb. "Of" is often confused with "have" in speech.
wrongExplanations: "Of" is not a verb and doesn't fit here.
"Are" doesn't fit the subject "I" in this sentence.

items.text: Choose the correct form: "Its/It's tail is wagging."
items.explain: "Its" is possessive (belongs to it). "It's" means "it is."
wrongExplanations: "It's" means "it is"; here we need possession.

items.text: Choose the best conjunction to complete the sentence: "I wanted to go, ___ it was too late."
items.explain: "But" shows contrast between wanting to go and it being too late.
wrongExplanations: "And" joins similar ideas, not contrasting ones.
"Because" would explain a reason, but the sentence is contrasting.
"So" shows cause/effect; here we need contrast.

items.text: Choose the correct subject-verb agreement: "The list of items ___ on the desk."
items.explain: The subject is "list" (singular), so the verb is singular: "is."
wrongExplanations: "Are" is plural; the subject is singular.
"Were" is past tense and also plural here.
